passage:
(1) Genetics is the scientific study of how traits are passed from parents to offspring through genes, which are the basic units of heredity. These genes are found on chromosomes, thread-like structures made of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) that contain all the information needed to build and maintain an organism. Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes, with one set inherited from each parent, giving us a total of 46 chromosomes in most cells of our body.

(2) The way traits are inherited follows specific patterns discovered by Gregor Mendel, often called the "father of genetics." Through his experiments with pea plants in the 1860s, Mendel identified that traits can be dominant or recessive. Dominant traits, represented by capital letters (like 'A'), will always be expressed if present, while recessive traits, represented by lowercase letters (like 'a'), will only be expressed if two copies are present. This explains why children sometimes have traits that don't appear in either parent but might be seen in grandparents or other relatives.

(3) Some traits are determined by a single gene, such as earlobe attachment or the ability to roll your tongue. However, most human characteristics, including height, skin color, and intelligence, are influenced by multiple genes working together, which is called polygenic inheritance. Environmental factors also play an important role in how genes are expressed, which is why identical twins with the same genetic makeup can develop different characteristics over time if raised in different environments.

(4) Genetic disorders occur when there is an abnormality in an individual's genetic material. These disorders can be inherited from parents, such as cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia, which require both parents to pass on a recessive gene. Other disorders, like Down syndrome, result from chromosomal abnormalities that usually happen spontaneously during cell division rather than being inherited. Advances in genetic testing now allow doctors to identify many genetic disorders before birth or early in life.

(5) The field of genetics has expanded dramatically in recent decades, especially after the completion of the Human Genome Project in 2003, which mapped all the genes in human DNA. This has led to breakthroughs in personalized medicine, where treatments can be tailored to an individual's genetic makeup. Scientists are also exploring gene therapy, which involves replacing defective genes to treat or prevent disease, and genetic engineering, which can modify an organism's DNA to produce desired traits. These advancements raise important ethical questions about how far we should go in manipulating the genetic code that makes us who we are.

questions.question: I have been waiting for the bus _____ twenty minutes.
While I _____ down the street, I saw my old teacher.
You _____ bring food into the library; it is strictly forbidden.
Have you ever _____ to Japan?
I usually enjoy _____ football on weekends.
This is the restaurant _____ we had our first date.
If I _____ you, I would accept the job offer.
This problem is _____ complicated for me to solve alone.
We used _____ in a small apartment, but now we live in a house.
The letter _____ by the secretary yesterday morning.
Look at those dark clouds! It _____ rain soon.
Could you tell me what time _____?
My brother isn't _____ as me at tennis.
She told me that she _____ busy working on the project.
You haven't seen my keys anywhere, _____?
I want to _____ rid of these old magazines; they are just taking up space.
Would you _____ holding my bag for a minute while I tie my shoe?
I'm really looking _____ to seeing you next week.
The team needs to come _____ with a new strategy to win the game.
He takes _____ his mother; they have the same smile.
I'm not very good _____ remembering people's names.
She managed to _____ up with her studies despite being sick.
I need to _____ some research for my school project.
Let's _____ in touch after you move to your new city.
She doesn't get _____ well with her new roommate.
The prisoner managed to _____ from the high-security jail last night.
She asked for a _____ room at the hotel because she was traveling with her sister.
We _____ the winter supplies in the basement them from being damaged by flooding.
The children walked _____ the beach, collecting seashells as they went.
The athlete broke the world _____ for the 100-meter sprint yesterday.
_____ healthy food is essential for maintaining good health.
She has had a successful _____ as a lawyer for over twenty years.
The medieval _____ in European history lasted approximately from the 5th to the 15th century.
I need to _____ to a different train at the next station to reach my destination.
Climate change poses a serious _____ to many species around the world.
There are many different fashion _____ that have become popular over the last century.
We collected _____ from the forest to build a campfire.
The furniture company will help with _____ your belongings to your new apartment.
She has a natural _____ for music and can play multiple instruments.
Some species of snakes have _____ venom that can kill a human within hours.
According to paragraph 1, how many chromosomes do humans inherit from each parent?
Who is referred to as the 'father of genetics' in the passage?
According to paragraph 2, which letter would represent a recessive trait?
What term is used in paragraph 3 to describe traits influenced by multiple genes working together?
According to the passage, which of these is an example of a trait determined by a single gene?
What is one cause of Down syndrome according to paragraph 4?

options.A: It is inherited from parents having Down syndrome in the second generation
options.B: It results from chromosomal abnormalities during cell division
options.C: It requires both parents to pass on a recessive gene
options.D: It is always inherited from the mother

questions.question: When was the Human Genome Project completed according to paragraph 5?
Based on the passage, what is a potential benefit of advances in genetics?
Which of the following best describes the main purpose of paragraph 4?

options.A: To explain how genes are inherited and how they can be enhanced
options.B: To describe genetic disorders and their causes
options.C: To discuss the Human Genome Project
options.D: To explain how traits are expressed through the genes

questions.question: What ethical concern does the passage mention in relation to genetic advancements?

options.B: The safety of gene therapy while manipulating genetic code
options.C: The extent to which we should manipulate genetic code
options.D: The availability of personalized medicine in the nearest future
